citation.article-title: Numerical and chemical classification of Actinoplanes and some related actinomycetes

p.s: Description of Actinoplanes palleronii sp. nov.
Actinoplanes palleronii (pall.er.on'ii. ML gen. n. palleronii, of Palleroni ; named after Norberto Palleroni, a distinguished taxonomist)
Light to yellow-brown substrate mycelium formed on modified Bennett's agar.
Sporangia spherical, spores motile and formed irregularly within sporangia.

Degrades arbutin, casein, lecithin, pectin and starch; utilizes D-fructose, D-glucose, D-maltose, D-mannose and D-xylose as sole carbon sources but not D-arabinose, D-cellobiose, dextrin, erythritol, D-galactose, methyl β-D-glucoside, D-ribose, D-sorbitol, catechol, coumarin, m-, o- or p-hydroxybenzoic acid, sodium acetate, sodium fumarate, sodium succinate, syringaldehyde, syringic acid or vanillin.
Neither hydrogen sulphide nor urease is formed.
The organism is sensitive to a range of antibiotics and chemical inhibitors (Table 6).
It grows at 4 and 30 °C, but not at 37 °C.
The peptidoglycan contains meso- and hydroxydiaminopimelic acid.
The principal wall sugars are arabinose, galactose, glucose, rhamnose, ribose and xylose.

The organism also contains complex mixtures of straight- and branched-chain fatty acids, with 12- methyltetradecanoic acid predominating, tetrahydrogenated menaquinones with nine isoprene units as the predominant isoprenologue, and major amounts of dip hosphatidylglycerol, p hosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylinositol.
Type strain: Actinoplanes palleronii LA83 (IF) 14916, NCIB 20021).
